text:
I added a HTTP Cookie Manager to my thread group (as described in the manual) 
but the recorded session does not record any cookies. when i select the HTTP 
Cookie Manager, the list is always empty. the tested websites (with cookies) 
doesn't work with JMeter, for this reason.
creator: mhilpert@gmx.de

text:
The HTTP Cookie Manager stores a different set of cookies for each thread --
which ones would it show in the GUI?

The GUI is only for cookies manually added there before the start of the test
plan, not for the ones that get received and resent during the test.

I'm transforming this into a low-priority enhancement request to do some GUI
change to clarify this.
creator: jsalvata@atg.com

text:
I have run into the same issue.  I created a HTTP Cookie Manager and entered a
cookie with a name, value, path, domain, and left the expiration at zero.  I
have tried all manner of domain/host specifications: .foo.bar, foo.bar,
hostname.foo.bar.  Under no circumstance is the cookie being sent with the
request (verified by ethereal).  Either this is not working or something I am
doing is not correct.

creator: mark.connolly@bcbsnc.com
andrew.clute@osn.state.oh.us
text:
I too have had the same issue. I have debugged it down to the clear() method 
inside of CookieManager. This method removes all cookies from it's properties, 
including one's that are StoredCookies from the GUI, or from the config file.

If you do not check the 'Clear cookies from each iteration?' box, the 
StoredCookies will stay there, but if you check the box (which I would assume 
*would not* clear the stored ones), it removes all the StoredCookies.

**HOWEVER**** -- none of this was able to be caught until I found a bug 
dealing with the Cookie Expiration. The logic to see if a cookie should be put 
on the header (getCookieHeaderForURL()) checks to see if the expiration is 
greater than currentTimeMillis()/1000. That is fine for cookies that are set 
by the browser, because they know what the current time is. But for 
StoredCookies that want to be memory resident, they should be able to set the 
expiration time to '0' and have it work.

So, the quick fix for this is to change line 292 in CookieManager.java from (I 
will sumbit a new bug for this):

 && (System.currentTimeMillis() / 1000) <= cookie.getExpires())

to:
 && ((cookie.getExpires()==0)||(System.currentTimeMillis() / 1000) <= 
cookie.getExpires()))

This will allow StoredCookies to be memory resident cookies, and not have to 
worry about expirations.

However, the 'Clear cookies' bug still exists -- it clears all of the cookies, 
and not just browser set ones. I think the level of this bug should be 
increased.

When using "HTTP AUTHORIZAION MANAGER" to log in.
It is suppose to send a cookie back, so I used the HTTP Cookie Manager.
But it doesnt work.

I used the tree listener and I got this as a return result

Access Forbidden
Please Note: Access to this web site requires that cookies pass properly 
between your web browser and this web server. Please check the following and 
retry your request:  
your web browser is configured to accept cookies.
  
you are using a fully qualified domain name in your URL.
  
http://server.domain.com/index.html is CORRECT.
http://server/index.html is INCORRECT.
http://123.123.22.22/index.html is INCORRECT.

text:
The upload function wouldnt work for me. 
I zipped the 3 files (since uploading here was only 1 file per post)

jmeter: jmeter.log, jmeter.properties, vrs.jmx

I'm not sure if u can log on to the server in the vrs.jmx since I had to edit 
my host file to get into that server.

http://www.geocities.com/aznfuman/jmeter.ZIP

Thanks ALOT for helping out. If I can return favour let me know

The jmeter.log file appears to be from a server instance which failed to start,
and does not show any test run activity.

The JMX file loads OK, but I can't access the host.

I suggest you move the HTTP configuration items so that they are children of the
Thread group and try again. [I'm not sure that they work when they are outside
the Thread Group.] For example, put them just before the first sampler.
creator: sebb@apache.org

text:
My supervisor got it to work. 

He kept the cookie manager/HTTP Authorization Manager outside of a thread.
He also left the Authorization Manager blank.

We used the Proxy section of JMeter to record and we ended up with
Browser-derived headers (<-- child of a HTTP request). The Browser-derived 
headers has 'Name' = Authorization 
Value = something.

That ended up working.

I think the HTTP authorization manager screwed me over. 

Thanks alot for the help!!

good luck!
creator: azn_fuman@yahoo.ca
